primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God enters human history to substitute His own righteousness for human sinfulness through the death of Christ.

tekstueel_bewijs: God has chosen to reveal himself
God made him to be sin who knew no sin

object.identificatie: Salvation / The Great Exchange (Righteousness for Sin)
tekstueel_bewijs: that in him we might become the righteousness of God
his perfect health is exchanged for our sickness unto death

zender.identificatie: God (as the source of historical revelation and justice)
tekstueel_bewijs: Our God has chosen to reveal himself... by breaking into world events.

ontvanger.identificatie: The Human Race / The Hearer ('The Slave')
tekstueel_bewijs: we might become the righteousness of God
he stepped into our place and took it away from us
Sin is a Power that holds all human beings in its grip.
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is described not as a mistake but as an ontological power and 'total incapacity' that humans cannot cure from within.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The ethical response of the believer to the mercy received.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The ethical 'wanting' to show mercy is a direct result of 'truly understanding' the primary soteriological program.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has entered history from outside history
God made him to be sin
voorbeelden_mens_subject: I do not do what I want
we are going to need more people like you
we go round and round in a cycle of selfishness

voorbeelden: we are going to need more people like you
we will never want to see another human being humiliated
it has never been more crucial... for Christians to understand
I can will what is right, but I cannot do it
incurably, irrevocably unable to cure the human race from within

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on human 'non-pouvoir' (incapacity) which necessitates God's 'pouvoir' (sovereign action).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from the historical reality of S2 (Cross/Death) to the human condition of ~S1 (Incapacity), resolving in S1 via the 'Great Exchange'.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Christ takes S2 (the wage of sin) so that the Receiver moves from ~S1 to S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; death is described as a 'rightful wage' and state-sponsored torture.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon explicitly identifies God as the acting subject and humans as the incapacitated receivers of an external rescue.

indicatoren_moralisme.indicator: Flattery of the audience at the beginning
indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: You are the avant-garde, the advance troops.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: The acting subject is not humanity... The acting subject is God.
Sin is a Power that holds all human beings in its grip.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Biblical figures like Elijah are used to show God's action in history, not as moral templates for the hearer.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Theocentric: God breaks into history through Elijah and Christ.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and gratitude; shift from performance to reception.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic salvation; the 'Great Exchange' is an objective work of God.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The sermon maintains a strict hierarchy where the 'Great Exchange' (Soteriology) precedes and enables the 'Mercy' (Ethics).
spanning_punten: The opening praise for the congregation's presence slightly clashes with the later emphasis on total human depravity.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: He has entered our condition to substitute his capacity for our incapacity.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon focuses on the Christological endowment of righteousness rather than the Pneumatological indwelling.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Total incapacity; 'incurably, irrevocably unable to cure the human race'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: Strongly theocentric with God as the primary Subject and Sin as a heavy Opponent.

subject_herpositionering.voorgestelde_herpositionering: Maintain God as the subject of active verbs regarding salvation.

identificatie_herstel.problematische_identificatie: The 'avant-garde' comment risks making the hearer the Subject of the cultural battle.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Frame church attendance as being 'drawn by God' rather than being 'advance troops'.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Introduce more 'vouloir' (desire) as a gift of the Spirit.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Show how the 'Great Exchange' creates a new heart that desires the good.

tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: The gravity of the cross is matched by the gravity of the 'Power of Sin'.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Keep the current order: God's Action -> Human Incapacity -> The Exchange -> Resulting Mercy.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a masterclass in maintaining God as the Subject. It avoids moralism by taking the 'Opponent' (Sin) seriously and placing the 'Object' (Righteousness) entirely in the hands of the 'Sender' (God).

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis might focus on the Newsweek hook, Greimas reveals the underlying 'Subject-switch' from man to God.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Goes beyond explaining Romans 7 to showing how the text functions as a narrative engine of rescue.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Identifies that the 'Great Exchange' is not just a theme but a functional actantial swap between Subject and Receiver.

volledige_subject_lijst: God (reveals, breaks in, enters, makes, shows)
appendices.notities: The sermon successfully follows the Rutledge Rule.
